title: Type inference with generics sometimes does not work with type annotation on the variable
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

Here is an example code to illustrate the issue

```rust
fn foo<T: std::str::FromStr>(s: &str) -> T {
    s.parse().ok().unwrap()
}

fn add_other<T: std::ops::Add<Output = T>>(a: T, b: T) -> T {
    a + b
}

fn main() {
    // This one works fine, as expected
    let a: u32 = foo("42");
    // This line works although it seems to be a similar situation to d below, type inference-wise:
    let b: u32 = add_other(foo("42"), 1);
    
    // This one obviously can't work as rust can't guess which type we'd want here (i32 or u32 or usize or whatever?)
    //let c = foo("42") + 1;
    // All of these don't work, even with type annotation(s) added
    let d: u32 = foo("42") + 1;
    let e: u32 = foo("42") + 1u32;
    let f: u32 = foo("42").add(1u32);
    
    // This one does work:
    let g: u32 = foo("42");
    let g = g + 1;
    
    // This one works fine, since the type annotation is on the generic rather than on the variable itself
    let h = foo::<u32>("42") + 1;
}
```

In this example, I expected type inference to work for d, e and f, but it does not work, although b seems to be in a similar situation and works fine currently. The variable's type is specified, but rust does not manage to infer the `foo()` call when using one of its type's method, either through `foo().bar()` or an operator (syntaxic sugar).

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

```
LLVM version: 14.0.0
```

Backtrace not relevant.

I saw some other type inference issues in the issue tracker, but none seemed quite like this one. If it's obviously a duplicate, feel free to close this issue.
